page.title: 18Thrumster Graveyard
page.content: Graveyards form an important link with the past.Thrumster's is built on the site of an ancient chapel and was used before 1877 although an even older graveyard served the locality.The present undertaker operates from Wick, 4 miles away.The old custom of kisting i.e.placing the body in the coffin during a service in the home for the family,neighbours and friends has now almost died out.So also has the black- edged invitation card,the funeral hats and clothes and the procession on foot with the coffin from the home to the graveside. News of death is intimated in the local and regional press and verbally.Women attend not just the service but at the graveside.The service is often conducted in a church or funeral parlour.Wreaths are still common but the gravestones are more usually simple granite slabs.
